Name: Västkustspelet
Description: Västkustspelet is a trivia game (basically a Trivial Pursuit: Genus Edition clone), with questions about the Swedish west coast.

Name: Space Voyage
Description:
Acting as a Commander in the Space Voyage fleet, players construct, crew and kit out a ship to voyage amongst the stars, seeking out rare minerals, avoiding alien races and trying to return to Earth as the richest Commander of the Fleet.

You start by trying to complete your ship, which is mostly a luck-driven process, before launching the ship into the void.  Once launched, players try to land on mineral rich planets, but there are many hazards to avoid.

The game ends when at least two ships have returned to Earth.  At this point there is a final semi-random determination of each player's holdings.  All loans are settled and the winner of the game is the player with the most money.

Name: World War II Game
Description: This is part of the Learningames History Series.  In it, you learn about World War II and the battles that were fought.    There are three levels of play included in the rules; Basic Game, Identify the Location of the Event, and Identify the Event Based on the Location.  The winner of the game is the player with the most cards.

Name: The Easter Game
Description: The goal of the game is to collect 2 jelly beans, 2 eggs, and 2 chicks.  Each player has a spinner with these objects depicted on them and the first to claim all of them wins.

Name: Price of Glory
Description:
From the publisher website:

Introducing our new WWI system, this is a stand alone game, allowing you to game small unit WWI actions. Rules include infantry, cavalry, artillery, vehicles, plus barbed wire, trench crossing, gas, and more. Troop lists are very flexible, allowing you to decide what you need to fight. Players of DH/C7B will be familiar with some mechanics, but you do not need DH/C7B to play.

Name: Seek Out, Close With, And Destroy.
Description:
From the publisher website:

This is Iron Ivan Games's new supplement for small unit and vehicle skirmish for modern battles. New rules cover Command and Control, Fire Doctrine, Rabble Factor, plus new equipment like ATGMs, Body Armor, Night Vision, and more. Extensive section on the use of helicopters, and modern aircraft. Also included are two conflict modules, War at the Bottom of the World: The Falklands (British and Argentine Forces), and Militia Wars of Somalia (Somali Militias plus US Rangers and Delta Force), which include appropriate infantry, artillery, vehicle, helicopter and aircraft entries. 52 pages in all. The main Disposable Heroes and Coffin For Seven Brothers: Infantry and Vehicle Small Unit Skirmish Wargaming in WWII rules are required for play.

Expands:

    Disposable Heroes and Coffin For Seven Brothers: Infantry and Vehicle Small Unit Skirmish Wargaming in WWII

Name: Red Sun, Red Death: War without Mercy in the Pacific Theater
Description: The first Theater Expansion for Disposable Heroes and Coffin For Seven Brothers: Infantry and Vehicle Small Unit Skirmish Wargaming in WWII covers the war in the Pacific with the Japanese, the USMC and the Chinese Army.
Families: Series: Disposable Heroes Miniature Rules (Iron Ivan Games)

Name: Futile Gallantry: The Fight Against Tyranny in the Early Days of World War II, 1939-1940
Description:
From the publisher website:

The Fight Against Tyranny in the Early Days of World War II, 1939-1940: Includes the information you need to field French, Belgian, Dutch, Norwegian, Danish, Polish, and Finnish troops. 80 pages of infantry platoons, artillery, vehicles and aircraft. As a bonus, information for the Continuation War Finns is included. Note: Early War Germans are found in Angriff!, Early War British are found in Go Forward Together.

An Early Days expansion for Disposable Heroes and Coffin For Seven Brothers: Infantry and Vehicle Small Unit Skirmish Wargaming in WWII
Families: Series: Disposable Heroes Miniature Rules (Iron Ivan Games)

Name: Trouble Catch
Description:
A boardgame based on the Japanese comic strip Urusei Yatsura. Each player plays one of four characters from the comic: Lum, Ataru, Mendo or Shinobu. The players compete to obtain presents.

Components include mapsheet, stand up figures, and 3-d presents.

Name: Hush!
Description:
Hush! is a children's game with no strategy involved, so everyone is equally good!

Each turn, a player turns over one of the hidden tiles. If it is a strawberry, then he or she can take it. If it is a bird, the collected strawberries are "saved" and put aside. If it is a scarecrow, the player must say "HUSH!", and all other players must put back all strawberries they haven't saved yet.

The game ends when all tiles are taken, and the winner is the one with the most strawberries.

Important hint from the rules: If someone has not learned to count yet, the players can stack all strawberries and compare height instead.

Contents:

54 tiles with pictures of strawberries, birds and scarecrows

Name: Sheriff of Dodge City
Description: A simple game in which players must spin a spinner to determine movement.  If a player reaches a space with an outlaw token they spin the spinner again to see whether they "hit" and capture the outlaw (picking up the token) or miss and have to move again.  The first player to capture at least three outlaws and get back to Dodge City wins.

Name: Let's F*ck!
Description:
From the publisher:

"Do you like to F*ck? If so, you'll love this f*cking game! Use the spinner to move around the board until one of your markers lands on the bed. Then you spin the spinner and start F*cking in the position the spinner points to."

Components: Board, spinner, four pawns.

Name: Porn!
Description:
From the publisher:

"Porn! is an easy-to-learn strategy card game where you and the other players compete to own the most porn movies. As you build your stash, you also try to prevent other players from building larger collections. You can steal movies by correctly answering a porn trivia question, triple your holdings with the Porn Mogul Card, and earn extra turns by filming a movie. Running out of cards closes the round, but watch out for the Arson! card that can destroy it all."

Name: Ninja School
Description:
Aim to attract the most agile ninja into your new Ninja School, supply them with equipment then send them out to attack other ninja schools to maintain your position as the best master.

Players collect ninja in 7 different styles of fighting, each ninja being of different strength. The game ends when one person has played one ninja from five different styles into their school or seven ninjas in total from any style. Points are scored for the value of the ninja and bonuses depending on how many styles are in the school and how many ninja are in each style.

Players may equip their ninja with items to improve their strength, stealth or weapons which are kept hidden until they are attacked or are sent out to attack another players ninja.

Name: The Wacky Tobacky Dice Game
Description:
From the publisher:

"The crazy game of pot slang! A player rolls the dice, then selects two of the dice and announces a unique two-word pot slang term. This term must make sense to the other players.
Examples are 'Bong Water', 'Pot Head', and 'Grass Brownies'. For 2-5 players."

Name: That's Disgusting
Description:
From the publisher:

"The hilarious drinking game where you and your friends attempt to OUT GROSS each other. Four gruesome categories and over 400 disgusting actions! Ham it up by doing overacted impersonations, name items that fit into vulgar categories, judge your friends in their efforts to gross each other out, and much, much more!!! Packaged in a dog poop shaped tin."

Components: Deck of cards, pad, pencil, custom six-sided die.

Name: Hump!
Description:
"The game of erotic education and sexual satisfaction!"

"You and your lover learn about each other's libidos while traveling around the game board. The woman asks the man erotic questions about how to please her, and the man asks the woman erotic questions about how to please him. Some cards offer general love-making tips and others are more personal to the likes and dislikes of the lover asking the question. The winner enjoys the reward of selecting three cards to interpret and act out during lovemaking."

"Includes: a durable gameboard, 52 Ask Him cards, 52 Ask Her cards, two game markers, a die, and easy-to-follow instructions. Packaged in an attractive game tin!"

Name: Noddy-spillet
Description:
The players searches for Noddy and his friends all around Toy Land by finding pieces of their puzzle.

The first player to complete his puzzle and return to the starting square is the winner.

Contents:

Game board
12 pices with Noddy and his friends
4 wooden pawns
4 puzzles
Die

Name: Zombie Wars
Description:
Zombie Wars is a quick tactical game for 2 to 4 players. Each player starts the game with a small horde of zombies. During the game you attack clusters of townspeople, adding those who die to your horde. Your goal is to build a zombie horde that’s large enough to annihilate the hordes of your rivals. If you have the most zombies on the board at the end of the game, you win.

Zombie Wars uses a custom board, tokens, and zombie horde tracker; a bunch of tokens; about 12 six-sided dice; at least two eight-sided dice; and a few ten-, twelve-, and twenty-sided dice. A four-player game takes about 90 minutes to play. Zombie Wars is appropriate for ages 15 and older.

Home Page: http://www.invisible-city.com/play/446/zombie-wars (free rules, board, and pieces)

Name: The Comical Game of Mother Hubbard
Description: Based on the nursery rhyme.  Be the first player to fill your cupboard with each of four items:  grapes, bread, fish, and a bone!

Name: Mitt aller første kryssordspill
Description:
Mitt aller første kryssordspill (My very first crosswords game) is a game that introduces children to the concept of crosswords. During a turn, the player must try to find as many letters as possible to a given word amongst the hidden letters.

There are two game boards, one for the smallest children with with all letters written down, and one for older children that can spell, with some blank squares.

Contents:

2 game boards
84 letter tiles

Name: Multimillionær
Description:
Multimillionær (Multi-millionaire) is a Monopoly-like game, but with more advanced economics.

The game includes a stock market, and if one player owns more that 8 (of the 10) stocks of a colour, he or she will get 50% of the income.

Also, there are no prison, only the "Ideal holiday resort", in which the players must pay (progressively more) to stay each round.

There is no income for a completed round, instead there is a dummy pawn traveling around paying rent to the players.

The game ends if all but one player are bankrupt, if one player has 2 million kroner in values, or at a given time.

Name: Månetoppen
Description:
Månetoppen (Moon Top) is a spin-off from the children's television show "Jul på Månetoppen" (Christmas at Moon Top) by NRK (Norwegian Broadcasting Corporation).

The players must collect as many blueberries as possible before the winter comes.

After finding a blueberry, they can immediately to the start square, or continue searching for blueberry, risking to lose the bucket and all collected berries.

Players
Contents:

Game board
4 pawns
36 månetoppen cards
45 blueberry cards
4 blueberry buckets

Name: Final Argument of Kings
Description:
Final Argument of Kings is a product of the same circle of players and designers who produced the Squad Leader board game and the Johnny Reb Civil War miniature rules.  Final Argument bears a strong resemblance to the latter but was designed to tune to the warfare of the middle part of the 18th century.  These rules are appropriate for games set from the time of the War of the Polish Succession (1734) to the beginning of the Wars of the French Revolution (1789.)  It is scaled to be appropriate for battle on the European continent.  For 15mm figures, one inch on the table represents 45-50 yards.

Horse and foot units are each four stands and represent infantry battalions and cavalry regiments.  Artillery batteries are single stands as are army, wing, and brigade commanders.  The number of figures per unit is variable with each figure representing 40 soldiers or one section of artillery.  Stand size is variable with the number of figures so that units with more men cover a wider frontage.  (The game would be playable with other basing systems, but the game's basing has a number of subtleties that transmit the tactical feel of the time.  For example, units are longer in march column than they are wide in line as, indeed, they should be.)

Turns follow a set sequence with simultaneous movement and fire of various types.  Each turn represents 20 minutes of time.  Players mark orders for units that are hidden from the opposing player.  Command is an important element but does not dominate the game or become obtrusive.  There is also provision for grand tactical movement so that maneuver and closing to battle may happen quickly without taking too much time nor sacrificing tactical detail.  Combat tends to be bloody with stands taking figure losses as a result.  Morale of units is a key game concept.  Units have a basic morale point that is altered by loss of strength and the local situation faced by the units.  Battlefield events trigger morale checks.  There are no saving roles.

Name: 1650 more Questions & Answers for use with Trivial Pursuit: Set I, Group I
Description:
From the Back of the Box:

1650 more Questions & Answers for use with Trivial Pursuit: Genus Edition...

Happy triviaphiles will recognize the Q&A's in this set from Set I of the award-winning Game of Trivia by the Avalon Hill Game company.

Now - we make these same questions & answers available for devotees of Trivial Pursuit, without having you pay for a complete game.

Here - in this box - are 1,650 additional Q&A's, color-coded for play with Trivial Pursuit (and other similar games of trivia).

And... if 1,650 of them aren't enough, check out the additional groups - labeled 1 thru 4 - to complete the set of 6,600 additional questions and answers.

OMNI Magazine - December '84 - selected Game of Trivia by The Avalon Hill Game Company... "best trivia game of the year, based on its variety of questions and low ratio of arguable answers."

GAMES Magazine - September '84 - editors' choice for GAMES 100 because... "Game of Trivia plays more like a true board game, and there's no reason why you can't use the questions for Trivial Pursuit."

Name: Kahovka: Wrangel's Kursk, Oct. 14, 1920
Description:
On October 14, 1920, the last major White offensive took place. It would become Wrangel's Kursk, a precursor to that more famous WW2 battle at Kursk but this happened at Kakhovka, a small town astride the Dnepr River.

Unique for it was only the second time in the RCW that a mass tank attack would occur (the first was in the Summer of 1919), fully supported by DH9A bombers and infantry against a very well prepared Red defense consisting of three consecutive trench lines, mines and barb wire. WW1 was in effect "revisited". General Wrangel placed his blind faith in the tanks he had procured from the British, His tankers were well trained. He had even developed a combined arms approach. His forces, though outnumbered by 2 to 1 or more, continued to fight the "good fight" and had busted out of the Crimea in June, sent the Reds fleeing backwards for hundreds of miles with mass tank attacks and the ideal flat land. However, Wrangel was unable to secure the town of Kakhovka. The town had little real tactical value except for the fact the Reds held it. In September, several battles had been fought for it, each time the Whites were repulsed. Oct. 14th would be the last one.

The Reds had created antitank formation consisting of MkV and FT-17 tanks and a unique American weapon, the Maklen 37mm AA gun. True, they only had a few of them , but the weapons ability to penetrate armor at very long distances was a stopper. Artillery units in AT mode also had been created. In manpower, the Reds had overwhelming strength if they did not flee from the tanks as they approached.

The stage was set for the massive tank assault (in RCW terms) and for the final show-down between White and Red.

Game scale is 1 hr turns, 800 yd a hex, company level, individual MkV, Whippet, Ft-17 tanks, Austin Armor Cars, DH9A Aircraft. The system never plays the same as once never knows how many units they can activate.

Name: Tesserae
Description:
Inspired by ancient art, Tesserae combines elements of dominoes and jigsaw puzzles to form a game of shapes and patterns. Since it doesn't rely on a square grid, tiles will fit together in interesting and surprising ways. The basic game provides a good blend of strategy and luck, while advanced rules allow for either pure skill games, or ones where luck is more of a factor. Suitable for solitaire, one to five individual players, and several combinations of teams.

The game of Tesserae pits players against one another, meshing colored tiles into the ever-evolving play field, each trying to exhaust their supply of tiles while preventing their opponents from doing the same. Skillful strategy can pay off, but be careful -- things can change on the luck of a draw! This is a game that will stretch your brain.

Name: Snowball Fighting
Description:
Designed specifically for play by mail, this is an un-copyrighted multi-player game of snowball fighting.

Players write orders for simultaneous resolution using a simple action point system. Options include moving, collecting snow, several types of throws and a number of specific actions with the board features (conifers, snowmen and a shed).

Name: Dutchman, Spaniard, Switzer, Swede
Description:
The game is designed to cover land warfare in Europe 1618-1660.  The emphasis is on continental warfare rather than the English Civil War.  Scale in one inch = 40 yards for 15mm figures, one figure = 50 men and each turn represents 30-45 minutes.

The basic unit is a regiment or brigade sized unit depending on the national force being represented.  These are then organized into Division which are in turn organized into Wings.  Two or more wings is an army.  During play each unit receives a number of actions called Operations depending on a variety of situation factors.  These are then used to execute movement and other tactical operations.

The rules provide diagrams of historical formations, army lists, and scenarios for the battles of Lutzen (1632), Jankow (1645 -- erroneously listed as 1635 in the contents page) and Anfangsthal (1644).  A separate expansion, called for God, King, Pulk and Orta provides additional optional rules as well as additional army lists for Eastern Europe and the English Civil War.

Name: Screech
Description:
Glow-in-the-Dark Concentration.

Screech uses a plastic owl that tells you the type of "insect" to find by showing the insect in its eyes.  Players search through cards and place the cards in the owl to determine if they have the right card.  (The owl has a flashlight inside the unit to flash the image on the cards to make them glow in the dark).

Name: Hive: The Mosquito
Description:
The Mosquito pieces can be added to a standard Hive set before the start of the game giving each player 12 pieces to play with.

During the game, they are placed in the same way as the other pieces. Once in play, the Mosquito takes on the movement characteristics of any creature it touches at the time, thus changing its characteristics throughout the game.

A Mosquito itself has no movement characteristics, so it gives no movement characteristics to an adjacent Mosquito. Hence a Mosquito cannot move if it touches only a Mosquito.

Exception: If moved as a Beetle on top of the Hive, a Mosquito continues to move as a Beetle until it climbs down from the Hive.

Name: Battleground: Crossbows & Catapults – Tower Attack Expansion Pack
Description:
Tower Attack is the first major expansion for the Battleground: Crossbows & Catapults.

Expand your Knights vs Orc battles with 36 new pieces.

Publisher: Moose, Melbourne Australia

Name: Battleground: Crossbows & Catapults – Twin Attack Armory Pack: Knight Battering Ram vs Orc Triple Catapult
Description: Expand your Knights vs Orc Battleground: Crossbows & Catapults battles with this three expansion for the Battleground: Crosbows & Catapults game.

Name: Space Explorer
Description: Described in the book Beyond Competition, Space Explorer is a cooperative game where players take turns controlling a space ship going from planet to planet.  Distance and direction is determined by a deck of cards (1-6 in four suits).  The game is a race against time measured in deck reshuffles.

Name: Do-To-Ho Table Hockey
Description:
Do-To-Ho Table Hockey is completely different from other table hockey games. The play figures are not fastened to rods, but are mobile on the whole playing field. In their bases just like in the puck there is a ball bearing, so they slide like ice skate runners all over the board. Moving a play figure is done via a short, unique knock against the figure with a small stick as in the case for billiard. The play courses take place alternating, there are 'attack courses', with which the puck may be played by a play figure, and 'position courses' (defense courses as well as offside release courses), with which a play figure only may change position without touching the puck. Puck possession changes, if the aggressor misses the puck or hits an opposing play figure. Do-To-Ho was developed in Germany and published in 1994. Until now (2007) there are about 200 exemplars, all handmade. The antecessor of Do-To-Ho was Stahlkugelhockey (=Iron Ball Hockey), developed by the same author in 1980. For more informations and a Video please look at 
www.tablehockey.de

Name: Weapons & Warriors Castle Storm / Pirate Clash Game
Description:
One player defends the castle with his soldiers, and the other player attacks it with his pirate force.  The first player to knock over all his opponent's men and target cannons wins.

Contains 75 pieces drawn from Pirate Clash: http://www.boardgamegeek.com/game/7184 and Castle Siege: http://www.boardgamegeek.com/game/861 (about half of each set).

Castle tower and walls
Pirate Ship
Catapult
Crossbow
Cannon
Mortar
Brig
3 Palisades
14 Soldiers
10 Pirates
24 Battleballs
12 Cannon targets
12 Latches
4 Palm Trees
2 Dice
Cardboard scenery

Name: Groups
Description:
From the author: Groups is related to Lines of Action, with the differences being that pieces in Groups move only one space, only orthogonal connections count, there are no captures, and the game begins with a drop phase. The game also bears a resemblance to Teeko, with the movement of pieces to attain a configuration, although in Groups a winning configuration can take any form provided all pieces are orthogonally connected. I had been playing it [the game with no jump rule] and found that it eventually bogged down with defensive play. I wanted to speed it up some, so I added a rule that a piece was allowed to jump over another piece to an empty space. I thought this would open the game up more. What I had found is that the game grew immensely more dynamic, and much more offensive, and finished a lot faster. What would go on from 30 turns for a game usually now finished up in under 10. The play balance seems the same now, but the game is a lot faster.

Designer's Note: For individuals who would prefer a more strategic, and less tactical, game eliminate the jump move in the game (see the entry in the variants section).

Online Play


    Super Duper Games

Name: Civilization CHR
Description:
Civilization CHR is an alternate gaming system for "Sid Meier's Civilization" from Eagle Games (2002).
Consider it as a group-up rewrite of the original game still using all of the original components adding new cards and pieces.

The game mechanics are similar to the original one but enhanced and revised to make it a whole new experience for a typical "Civilization" fan.

Civilization CHR goals are:
1) Add variety to game strategies
2) Reduce the "Risk effect"
3) Reduce Luck (introducing balancing rules)
4) Give a chance to catch up on to unlucky players
5) Implement some additional PC game rules
6) Increase realism and players interaction
7) General game speed up (slowed down by new rules) 
8) Better time management in slow phases or deadlocks
9) Having more "suspense" with destabilizing or unpredictable events
10) Increase simultaneous player goals

This boardgame cannot be purchased because it is free, so it has to be downloaded and "printed" from the publisher.  In addition to this, you must own the original "Sid Meier's Civilization" from Eagle Games.

Re-implements:

    Sid Meier's Civilization: The Boardgame

Name: Animal Fair
Description:
Card game with a deck of 40 animal cards.  As each card is turned over players collect cards by being the first player to correctly make the sound of the animal pictured on the card.

Link to rules now posted below.

Name: Allie Patriot Game
Description:
World War One era Patriotic card game features a deck of 48 cards for US, Britain, France and Italy.  Actually this card deck features 8 different games. 
1. Liberty Bond Game 2-4 Players try to collect the most Liberty bond cards while getting rid of all their other cards. 
2. Organization3 - 5 Players A bidding and trick taking game where the country listed on the first card turned over acts as trumps. You must follow suit, play off suit of use a trump card to win the trick.
3. Mobilization A memory testing game for from 3 to 8 players.Somewht like Go Fish.

4. Mobilization 2 Sort of a solatiare game with the object being to build up 8 piles with all of the cards from a particular conutry.

5. Mobilization 3 A two person game where you try to mobilize all of the cards that you hold.

6 Sham Battle  a bidding game where layers bid to determine county in power somewhat similar to game of canasta with different combinations being worth different values.Flag and Army of any nation worth 10 points, flag and aramy of Country in powere worth 40 points etc.

7. Sham Battle 2 try to accumulated different combinations of different cards.

8. Flag Game

Name: All Star Comics Card Game
Description: A trick taking card game featuring famous cartoon characters from the 1920's and 1930's.  The dealer turns a card to determine a penalty suit. If Krazy Kat, Ignatz Mouse or Offissa Pup are turned up, the dealer may choose the suit before he looks at his cards or he just turns the next card to determine the suit.  After all the tricks are taken, each player puts one coin in the pot for each penalty suit card taken. If  any players take no penalty suit cards then they win the pot.

Name: Car Wars Expansion Set #10
Description:
This expansion includes duplicate counters from Dueltrack and Expansion Sets 3, 4, 5, 7, and 8.  It also included a cardstock "spinner" that had to be assembled and whose purpose was to ease cross referencing handling class and speed to find resulting die roll for possible consequence.

Expands:

    Car Wars

Name: The Celestial Companions
Description: Marriage, Marriage is what brings us together today, Marriage, that blessed union that dream within a dream. Marriage is fun, Learning each other's quirks, spending time with your in-laws, and bouncing back from silly disagreements, who wouldn't want to do that for eternity? It's couples versus couples in this hysterical game where you and your spouse will discover how much you really know or don't know about your significant other! Newlyweds, couples with children, and even those celebrating their fiftieth wedding anniversary will enjoy this lighthearted lurch into eternal marriage.

Name: Resources
Description:
Described in the book Beyond Competition, Resources is a cooperative game where players take turns collecting resources on the game board.  The object of the game is to keep the distribution of the four resources between the players as even as possible.

Movement on the board is done by jumping when possible  or moving to a spot when not.  Bonus are awarded when all the players have the same number of a particular resources.  Penalty points for a resource are given at the end of the game for each resource another player lags behind the leader.  If the resulting score is positive - everyone wins; if negative - everyone loses.

Name: Pinky Lee and the Runaway Frankfurters
Description:
A frankfurter is placed on each one of the designated spaces along the track on the gameboard. In turn, each player rolls the die and advances one's own wagon along the track. The first to land on each frankfurter captures it and loads it on one's own wagon. Landing on an opponent forces the opponent to surrender all the owned frankfurters to the frankfurter hiding place at the finish line. The first to arrive at the finish line captures all the frankfurters that are there. The player with the most frankfurters after all have finished is the weiner (pun intended).

Pinky Lee was a Vaudeville comedian who achieved fame as the host of nationally televised children's show.

Name: Would You Believe?
Description: Spin and move game based on the TV show "Get Smart" .  Players try to help max recover the payroll that was stolen by agents from KAOS.

Name: Sorry About That!
Description: Spin and move game that came on a single sheet of cardstock, from which the player punched out the playing pieces.  Originally sold for 29 cents in discount stores.

Name: "Get Smart" Electronic Question and Answer Quiz Machine
Description: Trivia Quiz game baed on the the TV show "Get Smart".

Name: "Get Smart" Card Game
Description: Card game based on the TV Show "Get Smart".  Includes a peg board that is similiar to a cribbage board for keeping score.

Name: The Twilight Zone Game
Description: Board game based on the TV show "The Twilight Zone.

Name: Gomer Pyle
Description: Players race around the board, as Gomer Pyle, placing their men in to form a grand salute to Sergeant Carter.

Name: I'm George Gobel
Description:
Roll and Move game based on the NBC TV show "The George Gobel Show" which ran from 1954 thru 1960.

The game board features many of the famous "Gobelisms" that George would often say on the TV Show.

Name: My Fair Lady
Description: Children's game based on the Broadway Musical "My Fair Lady".

Name: A Trip Around the World
Description: Roll and move game with a travel theme.  Players visit exotic locations and world Capitals.  Starting and ending in New York.

Name: Bridge Dice
Description: Players have 3 rolls to try and spell B-R-I-D-G-E using the 6 custom dice.  If a player spells bridge they get 6 points, bridg  scores 3 points and brid  scores 1 point.  All other combinations score nothing.  The first player to 15 points wins.

Name: Bild-a-gram
Description: Players begin the game by selecting a word or short phrase as the target.  Players then take turns spinning the spinner that determines what letters they may take or how many letters they lose.  The first player to spell out the target word or phrase wins.

Name: Salomo Junior
Description:
Salomo Junior is an expansion to Salomo 3000 Bible trivia. Expansion adds 1050 easier questions for children and 700 questions for adults.

Expands:

     Salomo 3000

Name: Érase una vez...
Description:
Like in a memory game, you must pick up two tiles and if don't match try to remember it's position. But in "Érase una vez..." this idea is expanded, some tiles have special abilities that modify the game results.

As the title shows, in this game the theme is the Children's Tales, you receive bonus to match characters of the same tale.

Name: Dune Buggy Rally
Description:
Each player assumes the role of a dune buggy racer. Each player takes a racer and puts it on start. In turn, each player rolls a die (the rules says dice but only one die is provided), advances one’s own dune buggy that number of spaces,  takes chance card and follows the cards instructions. Landing on certain spaces and the cards award victory points. The player with the most victory points after all have finished wins the game.

The most outstanding feature of the game is its oversized (22 ½” x 36”) gameboard. The game is one of a series of “Gold Cup Games.”

Name: Horse Trail Ride
Description:
Each player assumes the role of a horse rider. Each player takes a horse and puts it on start. In turn, each player rolls a die (the rules says dice but only one die is provided), advances one’s own horse that number of spaces,  takes chance card and follows the cards instructions. Landing on certain spaces and the cards award victory points. The player with the most victory points after all have finished wins the game.

The most outstanding feature of the game is its oversized (22 ½” x 36”) gameboard. The game is one of a series of “Gold Cup Games.”

Name: Not at All Trivial
Description: This is a trivia game intended for play specifically by families, including children (and extended family).  The "trivia" questions focus on facts about the family members themselves (such as things they did while growing up, things in the family home, family ancestors, etc.) While not overtly religious, the game was marketed to a Latter-Day Saint (Mormon) audience.

Name: The Golden Plates Game
Description: This is religious-themed family card game has a set of cards which can be used in three different types of games:  "Rameumptom" is a set collecting game similar to old main,  "Who Am I?" is a trivia type game, and "Golden Plates" is a matching game.  The cards contain images and information about historical characters from the Book of Mormon, a book of scripture of the Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-Day Saints (Mormons).

Name: The Family Game
Description:
Loosely based on Chuck Barris' short-lived 1967 game show hosted by Bob Barker, each parent and child begins the game with a pawn on Start. The father reads a question aloud to one of the children and both write down their response. If the answers match, the father scores a card worth 25 points and he advances his pawn the number of spaces indicated on the card. If the answers do not match, the child’s pawn advances one space. The game continues with all players changing roles as questioner and responders. The winner is the player who scores 250 points.

Three of the spaces of the gameboard are marked "toy store". A player gets a chance card whenever landing here. Should a player land on the space indicated by the card held, that player is declared the winner immediately.

The game can be played by one family with the participants playing as individuals, or as a contest between families.

Name: Mr. Jack: Extension
Description:
A contest got the designers of Mr. Jack 137 ideas for new characters. Out of those 137 two were chosen:

     Steve McKeogh's “Spring-Heeled Man” who can jump over other people or obstacles
     Arnaud Fillon's “Abberline”, an inspector


The expansion contains these 2 new characters and 3 others designed by Bruno Cathala and Ludovic Maublanc:

     John Pizer, a butcher who frightens everyone
     Joseph Lane, an anarchist who builds barricades
     Madame, who can move fast, but won't enter the sewers


Furthermore, the expansion contains rules for a new way to set up the game.

Released: Essen 2007.

Expands:

    Mr. Jack

Name: The Great Chinese Railway Game
Description:
The Great Chinese Railway Game was supposed to be a remake of Reiner Knizia's Stephenson's Rocket.

It was announced in the late 2000s, and would have a completely new map - a map of China instead of England - and some rule changes.

Players are building railroads and try to gain influence as stockholders in 7 different train companies.

The game was never released, and the map developed by Knizia's team was used in the 2017 Stephenson's Rocket release by Grail Games.

Name: Up the Creek; The Salmon Survival Game
Description: Each player represents one of six species of Pacific salmon in their actual round trip from the spawning grounds to ocean, & back again to British Columbia.  Avoid extreme dangers, maintain health, or go extinct.  Rules for a basic and advanced game.

Name: "Struggle"...a game about life
Description:
Struggle is a game about life. Each player/team starts with $650. Every time you pass Payday on the board you earn $1,500. You can purchase things like Auto and Life Insurance and 'You're The Boss' cards, make investments and pay bills.

Once players pass Payday three times they will draw a 'Last Will' card which will give them a cash bonus or make them pay a cash penalty. The winning player/team with the most money after counting their cash and investments is the winner.

Name: Beat the Drum
Description:
Beat The Drum is a game for 'Salvationists' as stated on the front box. It is described as a fascinating trivia game for Ages 12 and up

Various questions in the categories of - Salvation Army, General Quiz, Old Testament, and New Testament are asked in levels of Easy, Hard and Master. By answering the Easy, Hard and Master, players advance their marker one, three or five steps respectively.

The winner is the one who reaches GLORY first.

Name: Mormon Baseball
Description:
This is a religious-themed trivia game for members of the Latter Day Saints (Mormon) church.  The trivia questions are religious in nature and are asked and answered in a mechanism simulating a simple baseball game. The key to the game is the question and answer booklet, which includes two pages of rules and 53 pages of questions. Each page has six numbered questions and answers. There is a cardboard field inset in the box and plastic pegs to use as runners.

For each "at bat", the batting player rolls a D6. For the first batter, the "pitcher" on the opposing team reads that numbered question from page 1. If the player answers correctly, he receives the result designated for that question. If he answers incorrectly, he is out. Pegs are placed on the field and advanced accordingly. One roll on each page provides a result without a question.

With each succeeding batter, the question moves to the next page of the booklet, allowing a long game before any possibility of a repeated question arises. As per normal baseball rules, three outs ends an inning and the team with most runs scored after nine innings wins. The game seems to expect high scores: there are holes in the scoreboxes for 24 runs by each team.

Many of the questions are very basic: "Who was the real father of Jesus?" (God). Others require more detailed knowledge of the Mormon church: "Name the brother of Joseph Smith whose name begins with the letter H who was one of the Eight Witnesses" (Hyrum), or "Which of the following is not an office in the Melchizedek Priesthood: Elder, Seventy, Teacher, or High Priest?" (Teacher).

Name: Cues 'n Clues
Description: This is a religious-themed party game aimed at members of the LDS (Mormon) church.  The game mechanics are similar to those used in the game show $20,000 Pyramid, and involves competition between teams to identify words on a list from clues given by a team member within a time limit.

Name: Fours
Description:
A simple game, played with 5 dice and similar in mechanics to Yahtzee, in which players get 3 chances to roll the lowest score possible.

At the beginning of each player's turn, they roll all 5 dice.  Then, they may set aside any number of those dice and roll the remaining dice a second time.  They may again set aside any number of dice and re-roll the remaining dice for a third time.  Dice you set aside previously may be re-rolled if you wish, and you may end your turn at any time if you are happy with your current roll.

Once the rolling is done, your score is the total of all dice, with a few special rules:

1. Fours are free, so you do not add those to the total.
2. If you have four dice showing the same number (except four), you subtract that many from the total.  Five dice of that number does not count.
3. If you roll a straight (all five dice in order sequentially), you subtract 4 from your total.

The game can be played with any number of people, and plays over five rounds, or however many you wish.  At the end of the five rounds, the person with the lowest total wins.

Name: Make a Painting
Description:
From the rules:  "There are 8 paintings in the game.  Each painting consists of 12 cards.

"Version 1: The aim of the game is to collect cards to make a full painting or paintings.

"Version 2: The aim of the game is to collect pieces to make a painting by memorizing their position on the playing area."

Paintings are by van Brussel, Constable, van Eyck, van Gogh, Ingres, Renoir, Seurat, and Uccello.

Name: Powarvasion
Description:
From the box:

"In POWARVASION(tm), two warring players battle to capture the other's government or three major cities.  Players alternate moving one of their armed forces pieces until the war is over.  These fighting forces move and capture in any direction up to their maximum range.  Strategy and skill are the keys to victory.  Players set hidden defensive traps, carry out hit and run raids and multiple captures, set up formidable geographical barriers, and launch nuclear attacks.  POWARVASION(tm) is easy to learn, fun to play, and a superior war game challenge!"

The board (with a sample setup, less the hidden traps and presumably cities) is shown on the back of the box.  9x9 square grid, Country Capital (white house), ICBM and Bomber (counters?) look like the King & Queen in chess, flanked by two sets of helicopter, artillery and jet pieces in the knight/bishop/rook configs.  3 tanks and 6 infantry round out the pawn row (tanks at ends and center).  From the board, it looks as if the next two rows you can choose where to set your 3 mountains; single river, lake and forest pieces, as well as two minefields and a missile site, along with between 6-9 "hidden" pieces (one side has 6, the other 9).

The side of the box has a picture of Col. James Jacobson, USAF ret., with a recommendation: "Powarvasion ...is an easy game to play, a thinking man's game of unmatched realism!"

Name: Anyone Can Par
Description:
Anyone Can Par is a golf simulation game.

The general rules of golf are followed.  Players tee-off by rolling up to 5 white dice.  The dice are added up and the total is multiplied by 10 to determine the yardage.  To simulate a hook or slice, the black die is rolled to determine which lane the ball lands in.  Shots from sand traps, putts and chip shots are done with special dice that have non-standard number distributions: 



    
         Brown 

         Sand Trap Shot 

          1:2:3:3:3:4 

    
    
         Red 

         Chip Shot

          1:2:2:3:3:4 

    
    
         Green 

         Putt

          1:2:2:2:3:4 

    


Alternately, these shots can be done by taking the appropriate card and following the instructions.  As the player's marker (ball) gets closer to the green, they will wish to roll fewer white dice to ensure they do not overshoot the hole.  Markers landing in hazards suffer penalties.  The course includes 9 holes with water hazards, sand traps, out of bounds areas, and trees.

Name: Rubik's Brain Game
Description:
Rubik's Brain Game is more or less a 2-dimensional Mastermind. As in that game, players take turns setting up a pattern which the other player must deduce, with the player making the deduction in the fewest moves winning the game.

In this game, a pattern is a 3x3 grid with each square being one of 6 colors, looking much like the side of a scrambled Rubik's Cube (the pattern is formed with 9 small cubes). On each turn, the guesser can either ask the setter if a given set of three colors are in a given row or column, or can ask if a given space is a specific color. In the former case the colors present and the colors not present are placed in different sections of the board for tracking purposes.

Name: Trivia Britannica
Description:
The object of Trivia Britannica is to get to London via the M25 motorway from wherever you started on the game board.

To reach London, you must have collected tokens from around the board. These are obtained by landing on token cities and answering a question from the category related to that city. On answering a question correctly, the active player can roll the dice and move again.

The standard game requires 3 tokens to get into London, the expert game requires 6.

Home Page: http://www.triviabritannica.com

Name: General Manager: The Baseball Business Game
Description:
General Manager - The Baseball Business Game produced in 1967 by the H & S Game Co, of Columbia, S.C.

The box is plain green cardboard, with the title  in a yellow label sort of area that also touts  the game as "educational & realistic," "for 2  to 4 players" and notes "New players  may enter the game at any time."

The folded green playing board has a generally *Monopoly* sort of layout, with five franchises per side (named only by city) taking the place of *Monopoly* properties and the white "track" interrupted by "Breaks of the Game" squares,  which also occupy each corner of the "track."  Each of the four sides of the "track" has a  semicircular "siding" featuring smaller squares  for "trades" and minor-league purchases. There  are cards for "player development" and lots of phony cash. (More information to follow)

Game listing comes from a compilation of games created by:

Yahoo Group ---- Baseball Games Group;antique baseball games to modern tabletop sims

More description of the game will be forthcoming from information received from members of the group.

Name: RoCo
Description:
RoCo was developed to answer a challenge, "You can't produce a race game that doesn't rely on dice".  RoCo is a simple game for 2-4 players.  If you can count you can play RoCo.

But can you win?

Name: Battle 3000: Come Defend Your Planet
Description:
Collectible Card Game where you aim to dispose of your planet's nuclear waste on another planet, while preventing aliens dumping their waste on yours.  Attacks are made by constructing an elaborate pattern of cards on the table and then announcing an attack based on the total attack scores of all played cards.

Published only in Australia and no longer available.

Name: Wiggul
Description:
Wiggul your way through to capture or display!

Wiggul (also previously known as Squiggle) was conceived as an update for the game Kasam. It includes the escort capture style of Kasam but uses a hexagonal board.  An additional aspect of the game is that winning can be by position (getting 5 pieces in a line).

Name: Xephyr
Description:
Xephyr is ideally designed for three players, but can be played with any number between 2 and 6.  Balance and co-operation are the ways to win in Xephyr.

Xephyr uses a dice; the latter is unusual for Fleur Designs games but it doesn't mean the element of skill is missing. The whole game is based on your skill of balance; can you get your first piece to its goal whilst keeping your second under control? If you can't then you can lose badly.

Name: Diversion
Description: Diversion is a simple game in which your move dictates where your opponent can move.  Do you go for speed or sending your opponent in circles?

Name: Qiddle
Description: Qiddle is a redesign of The Royal Game of Ur, with a design goal of adding meaning to the spaces while altering the layout of the spaces.  It pits player against player against player against player. Two or four compete but there are limited safe spaces and your resources won't allow you to keep to safe havens.

Name: Five
Description: Five is derived from an ancient Indian game like Ludo. Unlike all other games from this source, Five can be played without dice; then it turns into a game of pure strategy.

Name: Guide
Description:
Guide is a game of tactics for two players and extends some of the gameplay of draughts (checkers).  It is played with draughts pieces on a Laita board (irregular 4x5 diamond).

Instead of taking pieces from the board, as in draughts, captured pieces are stacked beneath the attacking piece and can be rescued later when their attacker in turn is captured.

Name: Gold Rush
Description:
Gold Rush is a game of alertness and fast reactions. The idea is to collect 5 identical cards and the grab a gold nugget.

This game comes with a board and specific places to put the gold nuggets. There are 62 cards with seven for each of the eight minerals (Gold, Diamond, Emerald, Silver, Platinum, Ruby, Copper and Iron). There are also six cards for Fool's Gold.

Name: Non Sequitur
Description:
Avoid reaching the 'Out' square (at the end of the board) by successfully giving answers that are within chosen categories.

Ex- If a category is 'State Capitals' each player must name a state capital in a clockwise rotation until a player cannot think of an answer or duplicates an answer already given.

The winner is the player closest to start when a player reaches the 'Out' square.

Name: Odds And Evens
Description:
Odds and Evens is a gas rationing board game that was created in 1979 at the height of the gasoline crisis.

Game components include 'Odds' and 'Evens' cards which aid you in moving around the board and collecting 'Ration Coupons', 'Gas Cards' and 'Credit Cards'.

Name: Cranium Squawkbox: Lunch Munch
Description:
It's time to eat! Lindy the Lunch Lady is cooking up all sorts of fun in her kitchen … like anchovy milkshakes and mashed potato pizza! Her wild menu is sure to have you giggling as you match cards together to create four-course meals. Once you've collected a five-meal feast for Lindy's cafeteria, you win!

Lunch Munch is portable, easy to play, and features an electronic Lunch Lady announcer for a card game unlike any you've played before.

What's in the box?
Includes electronic Squawkbox and 88 illustrated Lunch Munch cards. Requires three AAA batteries (included).

Name: Hockeypoker
Description: From the box: "Hockeypoker will fascinate the whole family, make up your teams, play cards on ice and score! Beware of the face-off! Outplay your opponents with strategy and speed! Move the puck to your advantage by playing your hand of offensive and defensive players, goalies and star players". Contents include gameboard, instructions, a deck of cards and five "pucks".

Name: White Eagles: A Panzer Grenadier Supplement Book
Description:
White Eagles is a 64-page book supplement to the Panzer Grenadier series, focused on the battles of September 1939, between Poland's defenders and the German and Soviet invaders. There are 40 new scenarios depicting both sides on the attack, battles of cavalry against cavalry, and even a tank battle or two. Plus of course background articles on the armies and weapons involved. This module is not playable by itself, but requires ownership of Eastern Front and Road to Berlin to enjoy all of the scenarios. White Eagles includes 165 die-cut and mounted playing pieces. Almost all of them represent Polish forces: tanks, cavalry, armored cars, infantry, machine gun, mortar, anti-tank, artillery and of course leaders. The book's format is the same as our very popular Sinister Forces and Fronte Russo books.

This game is part of the Panzer Grenadier series

Expands:

    Panzer Grenadier


Expanded by:

    First Axis: Slovakia at War 1939-1945 â€“ A Panzer Grenadier Scenario Book

Name: Scramble for Africa
Description:
You try to conquer the most valuable African countries. If you want to attack another player you have to declare war on him first, allowing him to attack you first. Also, there can be only 4 people at war at the same time; the fifth declaration of war ends the oldest conflict.

It's very homemade, including the self-drawn components.

Name: SuperSystem 2007 Annual
Description:
From the web-site:

"The SuperSystem 2007 Annual has arrived! Taking a cue from the long tradition of Summer annual issues in comic books, Four-Color Figures presents the SuperSystem 2007 Annual. This supplement for the SuperSystem miniature battle-game offers new characters, powers, and scenarios for added table-top comic book mayhem! Also included is a Fast-Play sheet summarizing the core rules, and with a bit of help from a grizzled veteran, providing enough guidance for a newcomer to try the game."

Expands:

    SuperSystem (Second Edition)


This Print-n-Play game can be found at:
http://www.wargamedownloads.com/item.php?item=569

Name: Oil Barons
Description:
Oil Barons is a board game based on buying and selling in the oil industry.

On a player's turn, the player rolls 2d6, with doubles giving you extra turns.  When you land on a square you get options to change your position on the board, such as buying/selling oil wells or opening/closing oil pipelines.

The winner is the first player to deliver a specified number of oil barrels to the Refinery, usually 15 or 25.

Contents of box:-
Playing Board
Rules
2 d6 dice
24 Bank Cards [similar to Monopoly chance cards]
1 pad of 50 Scorecards
225 Bank notes [6 different denominations, 5,000, 10,000, 20,000, 50,000, 100,000, 500,000]
8 White Discs marked OFF on one side, blank on the other
6 Hats [white green black yellow red blue]
18 grey Oil Rigs
72 Barrels [12 of each colour - white green black yellow red blue]
72 Flags [12 of each colour - white green black yellow red blue]

Name: The M25
Description:
The M25 is a light party-ish game revolving around the circular M25 Motorway.  On their turn, players pick up a card and do what it says - anything from a simple move to a full-blown charade, with drawings and lip reading possibilities.

By doing the action correctly, the player then gets to move further around the M25.  The aim of the game is to be the first to reach central London and find a parking space, which is done by rolling a 6 on a six-sided die.

Name: Ruined Urthe: A Djarhun Expansion
Description:
The Demon Tzerar had slain Gharad and taken the Book of Avrakar.  The entire land of Djarhun has been put into chaos.  Lakes of fire have consumed most of Djarhun, and only Durach remains...broken.   Tzerar has proclaimed his domain be called Urthe, where he rules with a ruthless hand.  Wars have raged for centuries to try to regain the lands.  Technomancers and Mages have been wiped out in separate wars that only solidified Tzerar’s power.  Gems have lost almost all value and the few that live, just try to survive on what they find.  The great City of Elidor has been long forgotten, as Tzerar’s castle now rests in its place.  The world, that was known by all, would surely be lost if not for one thing … none of this happened yet.

Welcome to the land of Ruined Urthe.  The expansion, to the Djarhun fantasy board game, can send Heroes on a journey 1,000 years into the future of Djarhun.  Explore the land that will come to be … if only you do not get to the Book of Avrakar in time.  This land holds new secrets and foes, as you travel the wastelands in search of artifacts that will aid you in the present.  Along with a new board to explore and updated rules, there are also new cards to add to the adventure...

• Hero Cards (11)

• Market Cards (36)

• Treasure Cards (110)

• Quest Cards (190)

Expands:

     Djarhun

Name: Snagglepuss:  Fun at the Picnic Game
Description: Memory children's game featuring the cartoon characters Snagglepuss, Yogi Bear, Boo-Boo Bear and Huckleberry Hound.

Name: Speedway: Big Bopper Game
Description: Car racing game that features a carnival type "ring the bell" mechanism that determines car movement.

Name: Gidget
Description: Teenage girl's game based on the TV show "Gidget".

Name: Gidget Fortune Teller game
Description: Card game based on the TV show "Gidget".
